t: Job 9
Then*p Job answered and said,
I*p know it is so of a truth: but how should man be just with God?
If*p he will contend with him, he cannot answer him one of a thousand.
He*p is wise in heart, and mighty in strength: who hath hardened himself against him, and hath prospered?
Which*p removeth the mountains, and they know not: which overturneth them in his anger.
Which*p shaketh the earth out of her place, and the pillars thereof tremble.
Which*p commandeth the sun, and it riseth not; and sealeth up the stars.
Which*p alone spreadeth out the heavens, and treadeth upon the waves of the sea.
Which*p maketh Arcturus, Orion, and Pleiades, and the chambers of the south.
Which*p doeth great things past finding out; yea, and wonders without number.
Lo,*p he goeth by me, and I see him not: he passeth on also, but I perceive him not.
Behold,*p he taketh away, who can hinder him? who will say unto him, What doest thou?
If*p God will not withdraw his anger, the proud helpers do stoop under him.
How*p much less shall I answer him, and choose out my words to reason with him?
Whom,*p though I were righteous, yet would I not answer, but I would make supplication to my judge.
If*p I had called, and he had answered me; yet would I not believe that he had hearkened unto my voice.
For*p he breaketh me with a tempest, and multiplieth my wounds without cause.
He*p will not suffer me to take my breath, but filleth me with bitterness.
If*p I speak of strength, lo, he is strong: and if of judgment, who shall set me a time to plead?
If*p I justify myself, mine own mouth shall condemn me: if I say, I am perfect, it shall also prove me perverse.
Though*p I were perfect, yet would I not know my soul: I would despise my life.
This*p is one thing, therefore I said it, He destroyeth the perfect and the wicked.
If*p the scourge slay suddenly, he will laugh at the trial of the innocent.
The*p earth is given into the hand of the wicked: he covereth the faces of the judges thereof; if not, where, and who is he?
Now*p my days are swifter than a post: they flee away, they see no good.
They*p are passed away as the swift ships: as the eagle that hasteth to the prey.
If*p I say, I will forget my complaint, I will leave off my heaviness, and comfort myself:
I*p am afraid of all my sorrows, I know that thou wilt not hold me innocent.
If*p I be wicked, why then labour I in vain?
If*p I wash myself with snow water, and make my hands never so clean;
Yet*p shalt thou plunge me in the ditch, and mine own clothes shall abhor me.
For*p he is not a man, as I am, that I should answer him, and we should come together in judgment.
Neither*p is there any daysman betwixt us, that might lay his hand upon us both.
Let*p him take his rod away from me, and let not his fear terrify me:
Then*p would I speak, and not fear him; but it is not so with me.
